newsitem.title: USA: New York jury deliberates reputed mob case.
newsitem.headline: New York jury deliberates reputed mob case.

text.p: A federal jury ended its first day of deliberations on Wednesday without reaching a verdict in the murder and racketeering trial of accused New York City mob boss Vincent "The Chin" Gigante.
The jury deliberated four-and-a-half hours before retiring for the day. The panel is weighing 21 murder, racketeering and other charges against Gigante, the reputed head of the Genovese crime family.
He was accused of ordering seven murders, plotting to kill three other people, rigging business bids and extortion.
The jury heard testimony from six mob informants and a dozen law enforcement agents during almost four weeks in Brooklyn federal court before Judge Jack Weinstein.
Deliberations were scheduled to resume on Thursday.
During its first day of deliberations, the jury asked to be read back testimony from two of the informants who testified -- Peter "Big Pete" Chiodo and Salvatore "Sammy the Bull" Gravano.
Chiodo, a former Lucchese crime family captain, testified that Gigante was boss of the Genovese family. So did Gravano, who testified that as Gambino underboss he met Gigante.
Testimony by Gravano was key in the 1992 murder and racketeering conviction of Gambino godfather John Gotti, who is serving life in prison without possibility of parole.

Gigante's defence attorneys argued the informants were witnesses willing to modify their testimony to suit the government. They also argued that Anthony "Fat Tony" Salerno was convicted of being the Genovese crime family boss in 1986.
They said Gigante -- who earned the nickname "The Oddfather" for wandering the neighbourhood around his Greenwich Village apartment in a tattered bathrobe -- was incapacitated by mental illness.
But prosecutors said Gigante feigned illness for years to avoid prosecution.
